thread.title: Alcoa, CAK battle for Region 2-3A title - PrepXtra
thread.title_full: Alcoa, CAK battle for Region 2-3A title - PrepXtra Story

author: Mike Blackerby
title: Alcoa, CAK battle for Region 2-3A title - PrepXtra
text:
No surprise that it has come down to this.
Alcoa High School tuned up for its regular-season showdown against Christian Academy of Knoxville with a 48-0 blowout Friday night against Red Bank in Chattanooga.
The Region 2-3A championship will be on the line Friday night when the Tornadoes host the Warriors.
Alcoa (8-1) is the top-ranked 3A team, followed by CAK (9-0) and defending state champion Christ Presbyterian Academy.
Alcoa and CAK have squared off in the regular season and the playoff quarterfinals for each of the last five years.
The Tornadoes have won five games in a row in the series, dating back to a 38-36 playoff loss in 2012.
"We've had some battles with them through the years," Alcoa coach Gary Rankin said. "There's a better chance than even that we might end up playing them again (in the playoffs)."
Alcoa had seven players score touchdowns in its win over Red Bank.
Taylen McNear, Karim Shereef, Kareem Rodriquez, Dustin Clabough and Malik Salter all scored on runs.
Tykee Ogle Kellogg caught a touchdown pass from Jaylen Myers.
Caleb Woody returned a field goal that was blocked by Clabough 85 yards for a TD.
Rankin said he hoped the win didn't come at a cost, as several Alcoa players were dinged up against Red Bank.
"They (CAK) are beat up a little, but so are we. We've got three or four visiting the doctor (Saturday) morning."
Region 2-2A Showdown: Much also rides on Friday night's showdown featuring Grace Christian Academy at Austin-East.
Both teams are coming off big victories.
The Roadrunners (7-2, 4-1 Region 2-2A) blitzed Sweetwater 50-28 on Friday night and Grace Christian (5-4, 5-0) defeated Tellico Plains, 25-7.
Austin-East got another strong outing from Darius Harper, a rising star at quarterback.
The strong-armed 6-foot-3, 195-pound junior completed 15 of 22 passes for 250 yards and three touchdowns. He also ran for two scores.
"He's coming into his own," Austin-East coach Jeff Phillips said. "No disrespect to any of the other quarterbacks in the city, but I think he's the best quarterback in the city."
Harper spread the wealth around among his receivers.
Kajuan Hale-Ligon hauled in eight passes for 110 yards, caught a 35-yard TD pass and returned a punt 66 yards for a score.
Wide receiver Kashif Warren Jr. (five catches, 119 yards) had TD grabs of 60 and 9 yards.
Defensive end Jimmy Rowans returned a fumble 54 yards for six points.
Keanu Prigmore and Shannon Cozart recorded eight tackles apiece. Cozart had four tackles for loss.
The Roadrunners finish second in the region with a win over Grace Christian on Friday night. A loss will drop them to third.
The Rams will win the region outright with a victory over Austin-East.
"This is the game that the coaches and myself pegged when we got the new regions and drew Grace as the last game," Phillips said. "It feels good for our team to be playing in a meaningful game this time of the season."
The Roadrunners missed the playoffs in 2014 after going 2-8.
Momentum Builder: It wasn't a region game, but Morristown East's 24-21 victory over Anderson County on Friday night gives the Hurricanes a boost heading into this week's showdown at Cocke County for the final playoff berth in Region 1-5A.
"It was a big game for us," Morristown East coach Dewayne Wells said. "With an opportunity to play that last game to get in the playoffs, we wanted to make sure we went in with some confidence."
The Mavericks (3-6) took a 14-7 lead at the half against the Hurricanes (2-7), who scored 17 unanswered points to take command.
Senior running back Bryson Stephens scored a pair of touchdowns for Morristown East, and Jon Koogler booted a 29-yard field goal in the third quarter for the Hurricanes.
Teed Up: Oak Ridge junior receiver Tee Higgins turned in a highlight-reel performance in a 62-6 win over Webb.
The Tennessee commitment had touchdown grabs of 31, 19 and 10 yards in the second quarter.
He finished with five catches for 77 yards and returned two punts for 76 yards as the Wildcats improved to 8-1.
"He continues to improve in all facets of the game," Wildcats coach Joe Gaddis said.
Higgins took over punt-return duties midseason and has proven dynamic in the return game.
After nearly breaking his first two punt returns for touchdowns, Webb opted to punt the ball out of bounds the rest of the way.
"Tee has turned into a huge weapon for us there," Gaddis said.
The 6-4, 184-pound Higgins has 41 receptions for 770 yards and 13 touchdowns this season.
He's closing on Oak Ridge single-season records for most touchdown receptions (16) and receiving yards (886), set by Antoine Thrift in 1991 in 15 games.
Oak Ridge hosts Campbell County on Friday night with the winner claiming second place in Region 3-5A and home-field advantage for the first round of the playoffs.
The loser finishes third and will go on the road in the first round.
Mike Blackerby is a freelance contributor.
